Accordion.description: A box-shaped musical instrument of the bellows-driven free-reed aerophone type (producing sound as air flows past a reed in a frame), colloquially referred to as a squeezebox.

Baglamas.description: A plucked string instrument used in Greek music; it is a smaller version of the bouzouki pitched an octave higher (nominally D-A-D), with unison pairs on the four highest strings and an octave pair on the lower D.

Bass.description: A musical instrument that produces tones in the low-pitched range C4- C2.

Bassoon.description: A woodwind instrument in the double reed family, which plays in the tenor and bass ranges.

Bouzouki.description: A musical instrument popular in Greece. It is a member of the long-necked lute family, with a round body with a flat top and a long neck with a fretted fingerboard.

Cello.description: A bowed (sometimes plucked and occasionally hit) string instrument of the violin family. Its four strings are usually tuned in perfect fifths: from low to high, C2, G2, D3 and A3.

Cimbalom.description: A type of chordophone composed of a large, trapezoidal box on legs with metal strings stretched across its top and a damping pedal underneath.

Electric-guitar.description: A guitar that requires external amplification in order to be heard at typical performance volumes, unlike a standard acoustic guitar.

Floghera.description: A type of flute used in Greek folk music. It is a simple end-blown bamboo flute without a fipple, which is played by directing a narrow air stream against its sharp, open upper end. It typically has seven finger holes.

Flute.description: A reedless wind instrument that produces its sound from the flow of air across an opening.

Guitar.description: A fretted musical instrument that typically has six strings.

Kanonaki.description: A string instrument played either solo, or more often as part of an ensemble, in much of the Middle East, North Africa, West Africa, Central Asia, Armenia, and Greece.

Klarino.description: A Greek clarinet; a musical instrument in the woodwind family that has a nearly cylindrical bore and a flared bell, and uses a single reed to produce sound.

Laouto.description: A long-neck fretted instrument of the lute family, found in Greece and Cyprus, and similar in appearance to the oud.

Lyra.description: A pear-shaped instrument with three to five strings, held upright and played by stopping the strings from the side with fingernails.

Mandolin.description: A stringed musical instrument in the lute family and is generally plucked with a pick.

Ney.description: An end-blown flute that figures prominently in Arabic music.

Oud.description: A short-neck lute-type, pear-shaped, fretless stringed instrument, usually with 11 strings grouped in six courses, but some models have five or seven courses, with 10 or 13 strings respectively.

Percussion.description: A musical instrument that is sounded by being struck or scraped by a beater including attached or enclosed beaters or rattles struck, scraped or rubbed by hand or struck against another similar instrument.

Piano.description: A stringed keyboard instrument in which the strings are struck by wooden hammers that are coated with a softer material.

Santouri.description: A percussion-stringed instrument which consists of strings typically stretched over a trapezoidal resonant sound board.

Tambouras.description: A Greek traditional string instrument of Byzantine origin.

Trombone.description: A musical instrument in the brass family.

Trumpet.description: A brass instrument commonly used in classical and jazz ensembles.

Tsampouna.description: A Greek musical instrument that is part of the bagpipe family.

Tsumbus.description: A Turkish stringed instrument of relatively modern origin.

Tuba.description: The lowest-pitched musical instrument in the brass family.

Tzouras.description: A Greek stringed musical instrument related to the bouzouki.

Violin.description: The smallest and thus highest-pitched instrument (soprano) in the violin family.

Voice.description: Sound made by a human being using the vocal tract, including talking, singing, laughing, crying, screaming, shouting, humming or yelling.

Whistling.description: It is achieved by creating a small opening with one's lips, usually after applying moisture (licking one's lips or placing water upon them) and then blowing or sucking air through the space.

Zournas.description: A double reed wind instrument played in central Eurasia, Western Asia and parts of North Africa.

Aegean.description: Music pieces originated in Aegean islands.

Arabic.description: Music pieces originated in Arab world.

Arrangement.description: An adaptation of a composition to fit a medium other than that for which it was originally written, while at the same time retaining the general character of the original.

Arvanitic.description: Music pieces that were composed and sung by Arvanites.

Central-Greek.description: Music pieces originated in Central Greece.

Euboean.description: Music pieces originated in Euboea island.

Ionian.description: Music pieces originated in Ionian islands.

Laiko.description: A music genre that is composed in Greek language in accordance with the tradition of the Greek people.

Melodized-poetry.description: Poems that have been subsequently set to music.

Mikrasiatiko.description: Music pieces originated in Asia Minor.

Newer.description: Music pieces that were composed during the last decades.

Nisiotiko.description: Music pieces originated in Greek islands.

Politiko.description: Music pieces originated in 'Poli', a name used for Constantinople (Istanbul).

Polyphonic.description: Songs that consist of two or more simultaneous lines of independent vocal melody.

Rebetiko.description: The urban popular song of the Greeks, especially the poorest, from the late 19th century to the 1950s.

Sarakatsani.description: Music pieces that were composed and sung by Sarakatsani.

Southern-Italian.description: Music pieces originated in Southern Italy.

Traditional.description: Traditional folk music has been defined in several ways: as music transmitted orally, music with unknown composers, music that is played on traditional instruments, music about cultural or national identity, music that changes between generations, music associated with a people's folklore, or music performed by custom over a long period of time.

Urban-folk.description: Music pieces that were composed and sung at big city centres before the development of the Rebetiko and Laiko genres.

Urban-light.description: A Greek version of the international urban music of the early 20th century.

Vlachic.description: Music pieces that were composed and sung by Vlachs.

Aegean-sea.description: An elongated embayment of the Mediterranean Sea between Europe and Asia.

Aegina.description: One of the Saronic Islands of Greece in the Saronic Gulf, 27km from Athens.

Aivali.description: A seaside town on the northwestern Aegean coast of Turkey.

Amorgos.description: The easternmost island of the Cyclades island group and the nearest island to the neighboring Dodecanese island group in Greece.

Andros.description: The northernmost island of the Greek Cyclades archipelago.

Arachova.description: A mountain town located in Central Greece.

Arcadia.description: A region in the central Peloponnese.

Arta.description: A city in northwestern Greece, capital of the regional unit of Arta, which is part of Epirus region.

Asia-minor.description: A large peninsula in Western Asia and the westernmost protrusion of the Asian continent.

Cappadocia.description: A historical region in Central Anatolia.

Central-Greece.description: A region that includes the southern part of the Greek mainland (sans the Peloponnese).

Cephalonia.description: The largest of the Ionian Islands.

Chios.description: The fifth largest Greek island, situated in the northern Aegean Sea.

Corfu.description: A Greek island in the Ionian Sea.

Crete.description: The largest and most populous of the Greek islands.

Cyprus.description: An island country in the eastern Mediterranean Sea.

Deropolis.description: A municipality located at the Greek-Albanian border.

Drama.description: A city and municipality in Macedonia, northeastern Greece.

East-Crete.description: The eastern part of the Crete island.

Egypt.description: A transcontinental country spanning the northeast corner of Africa and southwest corner of Asia via a land bridge formed by the Sinai Peninsula.

Epirus.description: Epirus is a geographical and historical region in southeastern Europe.

Euboea.description: The second-largest Greek island in area and population, after Crete.

Folegandros.description: A small island in the Aegean Sea.

Grevena.description: A town and municipality in Western Macedonia, northern Greece.

Halki.description: An island and municipality in the Dodecanese archipelago in the Aegean Sea.

Halkidiki.description: A peninsula and regional unit of Greece, part of the region of Central Macedonia, in the geographic region of Macedonia in Northern Greece.

Himara.description: A municipality and region in southern Albania.

Icaria.description: An island in the Aegean Sea, 10 nautical miles southwest of Samos.

Ionian-sea.description: An elongated bay of the Mediterranean Sea that is connected to the Adriatic Sea to the north.

Kalavryta.description: A town in the mountainous north-central part of the Peloponnese region.

Kalymnos.description: An island and municipality in the southeastern Aegean Sea.

Karpathos.description: The second largest of the Dodecanese islands, in the southeastern Aegean Sea.

Kasos.description: An island in the Dodecanese, in the southeastern Aegean Sea.

Kastoria.description: A city in northern Greece in the region of Western Macedonia.

Kea.description: An island in the Cyclades archipelago in the Aegean Sea.

Kilkis.description: A city in Central Macedonia, Greece.

Kos.description: A Greek island, part of the Dodecanese island chain in the southeastern Aegean Sea.

Kozani.description: A city in northern Greece, capital of Kozani regional unit and of Western Macedonia.

Kythira.description: An island in Greece lying opposite the south-eastern tip of the Peloponnese peninsula.

Kythnos.description: An island and municipality in the Western Cyclades.

Lefkada.description: An island in the Ionian Sea on the west coast of Greece.

Lemnos.description: A Greek island in the northern Aegean Sea.

Leros.description: An island and municipality in the Dodecanese in the southern Aegean Sea.

Lesbos.description: A Greek island located in the northeastern Aegean Sea.

Macedonia.description: A geographic region in Northern Greece.

Metsovo.description: A town in Epirus, in the mountains of Pindus in northern Greece.

Mykonos.description: A Greek island, part of the Cyclades.

Napoli.description: The regional capital of Campania and the third-largest city of Italy, after Rome and Milan.

Naxos.description: The largest island of the Cyclades.

Nisyros.description: A volcanic island that is part of the Dodecanese in the Aegean Sea.

Oinousses.description: A cluster of 1 larger and 8 smaller islands located nearby Chios island in the Aegean sea.

Paros.description: An island in the central Aegean Sea.

Peloponnese.description: A peninsula and geographic region in southern Greece.

Pogoni.description: A municipality in the Ioannina regional unit, Epirus.

Poli.description: A shortened version of Konstantinoupolis (Constantinople), medieval name for Istanbul.

Pontus.description: A region on the southern coast of the Black Sea, located in the modern-day eastern Black Sea Region of Turkey.

Preveza.description: A city in the region of Epirus.

Rhodes.description: The largest and the capital of the Dodecanese islands.

Romania.description: A country located at the crossroads of Central, Eastern, and Southeast Europe.

Samos.description: An island in the eastern Aegean Sea.

Samothrace.description: An island in the northern Aegean Sea.

Serifos.description: An island in the Aegean Sea, located in the western Cyclades.

Serres.description: A city in Macedonia, Greece, capital of the Serres regional unit and second largest city in the region of Central Macedonia, after Thessaloniki.

Sifnos.description: An island in the Cyclades island group.

Skyros.description: The southernmost island of the Sporades, an archipelago in the Aegean Sea.

Smyrni.description: A city located at a strategic point on the Aegean coast of Anatolia. Its name since about 1930 is Izmir.

Southern-Italy.description: A macroregion of the Italian Republic consisting of its southern half.

Syrrako.description: A village and a former community in the Ioannina regional unit, Epirus.

Thessaloniki.description: The second-largest city in Greece and the capital of the geographic region of Macedonia.

Thessaly.description: A geographic region that lies in northern Greece.

Thrace.description: A geographical and historical region in Southeast Europe.

Turkey.description: A transcontinental country located mainly on the Anatolian Peninsula in Western Asia.

Tzoumerka.description: A municipality in the Ioannina regional unit, Epirus.

West-Crete.description: The western part of the Crete island.

Zagori.description: A region and a municipality in the Pindus mountains in Epirus.

Zakynthos.description: An island in the Ionian Sea.
